Headline.Para: What next for the Korean peninsula?

LeadPara.Para: SINGAPORE - The flowery accolades wouldn't stop as the world's second most powerful leader all but held his nose to welcome the recalcitrant from neighbouring North Korea whom he'd avoided all these years and who now had shown up in Beijing for his first overseas trip as his nation's leader.

At the formal welcoming banquet at the North Hall of the Great Hall of the People, a musical pageant, and at another lunch at the Diaoyutai Guest House, Mr Xi Jinping and Mr Kim Jong Un, watched by their wives, got along like long-lost brothers.

TailParas.Para: Mr Kim, whose sanctions-hit regime has reportedly been sending out fishermen with little fuel in their tanks, often leaving them stranded on the open seas and freezing to death, spoke of a new Spring in ties. Preparing to sit down for what could be a landmark summit with US President Donald Trump, Mr Kim told his host that "from a moral and personal perspective, I should also brief General Secretary Xi Jinping in person."

The Chinese leader in turn proclaimed that their ties were the result of a "strategic choice" made by both sides based on history and reality, the international and regional order and in the wider context of Sino-Korean relations.

"It is also the only correct choice, and it should not and will not change because of one-time events," he added, possibly referring to China's endorsement of the strong sanctions imposed on its neighbour after its series of atomic and missile tests.

The bonhomie masks the nettlesome relationship between the two political scions who run nations that have a treaty alliance that dates to nearly 70 years. Abhorrent of disorder, Mr Xi had been hugely disdainful of his younger counterpart for the way he had allowed tensions to escalate on the Korean Peninsula, which falls in China's strategic underbelly.

"The most derogatory expression I've ever heard President Xi Jinping use was his description of Kim Jong Un," former US ambassador to Beijing Max Baucus, a six-time Senator, said last August. "He just does not like that man at all."

That the two were forced to make nice in a public way despite their poor personal ties underscores their respective strategic concerns after the sanctions-hit Mr Kim's bold gambit to offer direct talks with Mr Trump and his South Korean counterpart. Mr Xi's bald concern is that Pyongyang and Washington could leave Beijing marginalised. Mr Kim wants a Big Brother's protective shadow as he sits down with Mr Trump.

Mr Trump's latest move to replace National Security Adviser Lt Gen HR McMaster with the former State Department official John Bolton, who comes with a reputation of not always allowing facts to get in the way of his strong prejudices, worsens the situation for both. The US president would now have at his elbow a man with a marked preference for the use of force over other forms of persuasion and someone with a marked distaste for North Korea.

A decade ago, Mr Bolton, then a key figure in the George W. Bush administration, was among those responsible for the US ditching the 1994 Framework Agreement which committed Washington to "move toward full normalisation of political and economic relations" with Pyongyang. Subsequently, Pyongyang's steady thrust to improve the blast yield of its weapons and to launch it to greater distances - dramatically claiming last year that all of the US was now in its sights - brought matters to the brink of war, especially after Mr Trump took power in Washington.

Mr Xi would like Mr Kim onside for another reason. In the '70s and '80s the North often sought to play off the erstwhile Soviet Union against China to further its own leverage. In the years just before his death in 1994, Mr Kim's grandfather Kim Il Sung, the dynasty's founder, had sought to mend ties with Japan, South Korea and the US as a Soviet collapse loomed. It was from these efforts that the Framework Agreement with the US, which Mr Bolton helped to shred , had emerged.

The failure of this, and subsequent efforts to build a better Pyongyang-Washington relationship were seen by Beijing as a deliberate gambit by the US to keep the Korean peninsula on a perpetual boil and thus have an excuse to maintainnuclear weapons onChina's periphery.

Mr Kim, according to Beijing, has reiterated that he is willing to commit to "denuclearisation" - as demanded by the Trump administration. This is entirely in line with what his government told envoys from South Korea earlier this month.

"The North also made clear that there is no reason for them to possess nuclear weapons as long as military threats to the North are eliminated and the regime's security is guaranteed," read the statement put out by Seoul.
The question now is what next?

Mr Trump, after all his threats of raining fire on Pyongyang, cannot afford to have a sit-down with Mr Kim only for the cameras. At the same time, it is difficult to envisage Mr Kim signing on to a deal that would make him give up his nuclear weapons without rock solid guarantees of personal and regime security from the US president. The young North Korean is doubtless aware that both Saddam Hussein in Iraq and Moammar Gaddafi in Libya were toppled after they agreed to stop developing a nuclear weapon.

With most of his life still ahead of him, Mr Kim would not like to see their fate repeated with him - hence the North's penchant to call its small nuclear arsenal "the treasured sword of justice". In this regard, the China alliance gives him a measure of comfort, no matter how poor his ties with Mr Xi may be. The effusive sentiments Mr Kim expressed to Mr Xi after the latter's success in consolidating power at last year's 19th Party Congress were clearly made with an eye to the diplomatic maneouvres he was contemplating. Hence, the tip of the hat to Mr Xi this week.

Likewise, China needs the Kim government to be intact lest a regime collapse lead to a messy reunification between the North and the South that could see US troops head north to the Yalu River, thus depriving China of the comfort of a buffer state in one corner at a time when its ties with Japan and India are rather fraught.

It is important for all concerned, therefore, that a Trump-Kim summit makes progress. It would be in no one's interest for Mr Kim to head back to his nuclear factory - already there is pressure on Seoul and Tokyo to reverse their policies on nuclear weapons in order to counter the North, making China uncomfortable at the prospect of two US allies at its doorstep acquiring strategic weapons. The US could do much to assuage China's own concerns by not only keeping it fully abreast of the negotiations but eventually bringing it in as a fourth partner alongside itself, South Korea and Japan - if talks produce an agreement to help the North climb out of its distressed economic situation.
